question: Which among the following is a bacterial disease?
solution:
• Leprosy (also known as Hansen’s disease) is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium leprae
  • It primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves, eyes, and respiratory tract
  • The disease spreads through long-term close contact with an infected person, not casual contact
  • It causes skin lesions, numbness, and in untreated cases, deformities

Additional Information:

  • Rabies: Caused by the Rabies virus, spread through animal bites
  • Malaria: Caused by the Plasmodium parasite, transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes
  • Ebola: Caused by the Ebola virus, spread through direct contact with bodily fluids of infected persons or animals

question:
Which of the following pairs of disease-duration is correct?

Acute-long duration

Chronic-short time
option_2: Neither I nor II
option_4: Both I and II
solution:
• Acute diseases are those that occur suddenly and last for a short duration, such as cold, fever, or influenza.
  • Chronic diseases develop slowly but last for a long time, often for months or years — like diabetes, hypertension, or arthritis.
  • Therefore, both statements given in the question are incorrect.

Additional Information:

  • Acute = Short duration, fast onset
  • Chronic = Long duration, slow progression
  • Identifying the nature of a disease (acute or chronic) helps in selecting proper treatment and management strategy

question: _______ diseases last for only shorter periods of time.
solution:
• Acute diseases are illnesses that begin suddenly and last for a short duration, usually a few days to a few weeks
  • They often resolve quickly with or without medical treatment
  • Examples include cold, fever, diarrhea, and influenza

Additional Information:

  • Chronic diseases last for a long period (months or years), e.g., asthma, hypertension
  • Hereditary diseases are passed from parents to children via genes
  • Genetic diseases result from mutations in DNA and may or may not be inherited

question: Which of the following disease is caused by fungi?
solution:
• Ringworm is a fungal infection, not caused by a worm despite the name.
  • It affects the skin, scalp, feet, or nails, forming circular red itchy rashes.
  • It is caused by dermatophyte fungi, such as Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton.
  • It spreads through direct contact with infected individuals, animals, or contaminated surfaces.

Additional Information:

  • Covid-19: Caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus
  • Tuberculosis: Caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Cholera: Caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae
  • Fungal diseases are treated with antifungal medications, unlike bacterial or viral diseases

question: Which among the following is a viral disease?
solution:
• Chicken Pox is a viral disease caused by the Varicella-zoster virus (VZV)
  • It is highly contagious and spreads through airborne droplets or direct contact with fluid from blisters
  • Symptoms include:
    • Fever
    • Itchy rash with red spots and blisters
    • Fatigue and body ache
  • Mostly occurs in children, and in most cases, it resolves on its own

Additional Information:

  • Tuberculosis: Caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Whooping Cough: Also known as pertussis, caused by Bordetella pertussis bacteria
  • Malaria: Caused by the Plasmodium parasite, spread by Anopheles mosquitoes

question:
Which of the following options is correct regarding sexually transmitted disease (STD)?

Statement A: Sexually transmitted disease (STD) are infections transmitted from an infected person to an uninfected person through sexual contact.

Statement B: HIV, HPV and Hepatitis B virus is responsible for STD.
option_1: Both Statements A and B incorrect
option_2: Only Statement B is correct
option_3: Both Statements A and B correct
option_4: Only Statement A is correct
solution:
• Statement A is correct:

    Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) are infections spread through sexual contact (vaginal, oral, or anal) with an infected person. This includes both viral and bacterial infections.

  • Statement B is also correct:
    • HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus): Causes AIDS and spreads through sexual contact, blood, or from mother to child
    • HPV (Human Papillomavirus): A common STD that can cause genital warts and cervical cancer
    • Hepatitis B Virus: Can also be sexually transmitted and affects the liver

Additional Information:

  • Other STDs include Syphilis, Gonorrhoea, Chlamydia, Herpes simplex virus (HSV).
  • Many STDs are preventable through safe sex practices, including condom use.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications and further transmission.

question: Deficiency of which of the following vitamins causes excessive bleeding from wounds?
solution:
• Vitamin K plays a crucial role in the blood clotting process
  • It helps in the synthesis of clotting factors (like prothrombin) in the liver
  • Deficiency of Vitamin K leads to delayed clotting, resulting in excessive bleeding from minor wounds
  • It is fat-soluble and found in green leafy vegetables, dairy, and liver

Additional Information:

  • Vitamin D: Essential for bone health and calcium absorption
  • Vitamin E: Acts as an antioxidant, protects cells from damage
  • Vitamin A: Important for vision, skin health, and immune function
  • Vitamin K deficiency is more common in newborns and those on long-term antibiotics

question:
Match column A with column B.

Column – A

Column – B

Kwashiorkor

Weak bones and muscles

Anemia

Goitre

Iodine deficiency

Iron deficiency

Calcium deficiency

Protein deficiency
option_1: I-c, II-b, III-d, IV-a
option_2: I-b, II-a, III-c, IV-d
option_3: I-d, II-c, III-b, IV-a
option_4: I-b, II-c, III-a, IV-d
solution:
• Kwashiorkor → Protein deficiency

    A form of severe protein malnutrition in children, causing edema, weakness, and growth failure

  • Weak bones and muscles → Calcium deficiency

    Leads to rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults

  • Anemia → Iron deficiency

    Causes reduced hemoglobin, leading to fatigue and pale skin

  • Goitre → Iodine deficiency

    Causes thyroid gland enlargement due to low thyroxine hormone

Additional Information:

  • Protein is essential for growth and repair of tissues
  • Calcium is vital for bone strength, teeth, and muscle function
  • Iron helps in oxygen transport via hemoglobin
  • Iodine is needed for thyroid hormone production

question:
Which of the following pairs of plant diseases – microorganisms is correct?

Citrus canker – Virus

Rust of Wheat - Fungi
option_2: Neither I nor II
option_4: Both I and II
solution:
• Citrus canker is caused by a bacterium, specifically Xanthomonas axonopodis, not a virus. So Statement I is incorrect.
  • Rust of Wheat is caused by fungi, mainly Puccinia graminis. It affects wheat leaves and stems, causing reddish-brown rust spots. So Statement II is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Citrus canker leads to lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit of citrus plants; spreads through wind-driven rain and tools.
  • Rust of wheat can significantly reduce crop yield if not controlled; spreads by wind-borne fungal spores.
  • Common plant diseases:
    • Late blight of potato – Phytophthora infestans (fungus-like)
    • Yellow vein mosaic of okra – Virus
    • Wilt of cotton – Fusarium fungus

question: _________ is a technique in which cancer cells are damaged with radiation, while limiting the harm to nearby healthy tissue.
solution:
• Radiotherapy is a medical treatment that uses high-energy radiation (like X-rays or gamma rays) to destroy or shrink cancer cells.
  • The goal is to target cancerous tissue precisely while sparing as much healthy tissue as possible.
  • It is often used in combination with surgery or chemotherapy, depending on the type and stage of cancer.

Additional Information:

  • Chemotherapy: Uses anticancer drugs, not radiation, to kill or stop the growth of cancer cells throughout the body.
  • Surgery: Physically removes the tumor from the body.
  • Physiotherapy: A rehabilitation method to restore movement and function, not related to cancer treatment.

question: Typhoid fever is caused by _______.
solution:
• Typhoid fever is caused by a bacterium named Salmonella typhi.
  • It spreads through contaminated food or water, and is common in areas with poor sanitation.
  • Symptoms include:
    • Prolonged high fever
    • Weakness and fatigue
    • Abdominal pain
    • Rashes (rose spots) on the body

Additional Information:

  • Diagnosis is done through tests like Widal test and blood culture.
  • Preventive measures include good hygiene, safe drinking water, and vaccination.
  • It is treated using antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin or azithromycin.

question: Athlete’s foot is a disease caused by _________.
solution:
• Athlete’s foot is a fungal infection that affects the skin of the feet, particularly between the toes.
  • It is caused by dermatophyte fungi, such as Trichophyton species.
  • The condition is common in warm, moist environments, like locker rooms, swimming pools, and sweaty shoes.
  • Symptoms include:
    • Itching and burning
    • Peeling or cracked skin
    • Redness and blisters

Additional Information:

  • It is highly contagious and spreads through direct contact or contaminated surfaces.
  • Treated with antifungal creams, powders, or oral medications.
  • Preventive tips:
    • Keep feet clean and dry
    • Avoid walking barefoot in public showers or locker rooms
    • Change socks and shoes regularly

question: How is tuberculosis spread in humans?
solution:
• Tuberculosis (TB) is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • It spreads from person to person through the air via droplet infection.
  • When an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks, or spits, they release tiny droplets containing bacteria, which can be inhaled by others.
  • It primarily affects the lungs, but can also spread to other parts of the body.

Additional Information:

  • TB is not spread by:
    • Touching surfaces or people
    • Sharing food or water
    • Contact with soil
  • Diagnosis: Chest X-ray, sputum test, Mantoux test
  • TB is preventable and treatable with proper antibiotic therapy (e.g. DOTS).
  • BCG vaccine is given to protect against severe TB in children.

question: Which of the following is NOT a symptom of Beriberi caused due to the deficiency of Vitamin B1?
option_4: Pain in the limbs
solution:
• Beriberi is a disease caused by Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency.
  • It primarily affects the nervous system (dry beriberi) and the cardiovascular system (wet beriberi).
  • Common symptoms include:
    • Muscle weakness and pain in the limbs
    • Difficulty in speaking
    • Involuntary eye movements (nystagmus)
    • Edema or shortness of breath in wet beriberi
  • Slowly healing wounds are not a symptom of thiamine deficiency. This symptom is more associated with deficiencies in Vitamin C (scurvy) or zinc.

Additional Information:

  • Vitamin B1 helps convert carbohydrates into energy and is essential for nerve function.
  • Major sources include: whole grains, legumes, nuts, and seeds.
  • Beriberi is common in populations with a diet high in polished rice.

question: Which disease refers to the inflammation of the liver caused by a variety of infectious viruses and non-infectious agents leading to a variety of health problems?
solution:
• Hepatitis refers to inflammation of the liver.
  • It can be caused by infectious viruses (like Hepatitis A, B, C, D, and E) or non-infectious agents such as alcohol, drugs, or autoimmune diseases.
  • Hepatitis can lead to acute illness or chronic liver damage, including cirrhosis or liver cancer.
  • It affects liver functions like detoxification, protein synthesis, and bile production.

Additional Information:

  • Hepatitis A and E are usually spread through contaminated food or water.
  • Hepatitis B, C, and D are transmitted via blood, sexual contact, or from mother to child.
  • Vaccines are available for Hepatitis A and B.

question: Identify the disease that is caused due to inadequate secretion of the hormone insulin from the Pancreas?
solution:
• Diabetes mellitus is caused by the inadequate secretion or action of insulin.
  • Insulin is a hormone secreted by the pancreas that helps regulate blood glucose levels.
  • When insulin is insufficient or ineffective, glucose builds up in the blood, leading to diabetes.
  • There are two main types:
    • Type 1 Diabetes: Body does not produce insulin.
    • Type 2 Diabetes: Body becomes resistant to insulin or doesn’t produce enough.

Additional Information:

  • Symptoms include: frequent urination, excessive thirst, fatigue, and slow-healing wounds.
  • Long-term complications: heart disease, nerve damage, kidney failure, vision loss.

question: Identify the disease caused by a monkey bite.
solution:
• Rabies is a viral disease that can be transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal, including monkeys, dogs, cats, bats, etc.
  • The virus attacks the central nervous system, leading to brain inflammation and, if untreated, is almost always fatal.
  • It is caused by the Rabies virus, from the Rhabdoviridae family.

Additional Information:

  • Immediate post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), including rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin, is crucial after a suspected bite.
  • Symptoms include: fever, headache, anxiety, confusion, hallucinations, and paralysis.
  • India has a high burden of rabies cases, largely due to stray animals.

question: What disease in adults means ‘soft bones’ that usually develops due to a deficiency of vitamin D (often from not getting enough sunlight), or less often, digestive or kidney disease?
solution:
• Osteomalacia refers to "softening of bones" in adults, primarily due to Vitamin D deficiency.
  • Vitamin D is essential for calcium absorption, and its lack leads to poor bone mineralization.
  • Without enough calcium and phosphate, bones become soft, weak, and more likely to bend or fracture.
  • Common causes:
    • Inadequate sunlight exposure
    • Poor dietary intake of vitamin D
    • Kidney or digestive disorders affecting absorption

Additional Information:

  • Symptoms: bone pain (especially in the hips), muscle weakness, difficulty walking, frequent fractures.
  • In children, a similar condition is called Rickets.
  • Treatment involves vitamin D and calcium supplementation.

question: Identify a way that does NOT prevent a non-communicable disease from occurring in someone.
solution:
• Non-communicable diseases (NCDs) are not spread from person to person. They include conditions like diabetes, hypertension, heart disease, and cancer.
  • Common preventive measures include:
    • Adequate sleep
    • Balanced and healthy diet
    • Regular physical activity
    • Avoiding tobacco and alcohol
  • Blood transfusion is not a preventive measure for non-communicable diseases. It is a medical treatment often used in conditions like severe anemia or blood loss, but it doesn't prevent NCDs.

Additional Information:

  • NCDs are mostly linked to lifestyle and environmental factors.
  • Prevention focuses on promoting healthy habits and regular health check-ups.

question: Poor sanitation conditions may NOT be the likely reason behind which of the following diseasesconditions?
solution:
• Arthritis is a condition involving inflammation of the joints, often caused by autoimmune disorders, aging, or injury, not by infections or poor sanitation.
  • It is classified as a non-communicable disease.
  • On the other hand:
    • Typhoid, Cholera, and Polio are infectious diseases commonly spread through contaminated water, food, or unhygienic conditions.
    • Poor sanitation is a major risk factor for these diseases.

Additional Information:

  • Typhoid is caused by Salmonella typhi.
  • Cholera is caused by Vibrio cholerae.
  • Polio is caused by the Poliovirus, transmitted via the fecal-oral route.
  • Arthritis may require long-term lifestyle and medical management but not hygiene-based prevention.

question: Which of the following diseases CANNOT be prevented by vaccination?
solution:
• Beri beri is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine), not by any bacteria or virus.
  • Since it is a nutritional deficiency disorder, it cannot be prevented through vaccination. Prevention is through a diet rich in thiamine.
  • In contrast:
    • Rabies – Preventable by rabies vaccine
    • Typhoid – Preventable by typhoid vaccine
    • Measles – Preventable by MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella) vaccine

Additional Information:

  • Beri beri has two forms:
    • Dry Beriberi: Affects the nervous system
    • Wet Beriberi: Affects the heart and circulatory system
  • Rich sources of Vitamin B1: whole grains, legumes, nuts

question: According to the world Health Organization (WHO), “Hygiene refers to ________ and practices that help to maintain ____ and _____ the spread of diseases.”
solution:
• According to the World Health Organization (WHO), hygiene refers to “conditions and practices that help to maintain health and prevent the spread of diseases.”
  • This definition emphasizes two key aspects:
    • Maintaining health
    • Preventing disease transmission
  • Option (d) matches this exact phrasing and context.

Additional Information:

  • Examples of hygiene practices include:
    • Handwashing with soap
    • Safe food preparation
    • Clean drinking water
    • Proper sanitation and waste disposal

question: Which of the following is a type of plant disease?
solution:
• Blight is a plant disease that causes rapid browning, wilting, and death of plant tissues, typically leaves and stems.
  • It is caused by various fungi, bacteria, or viruses.
  • Famous examples:
    • Late blight in potatoes (caused by Phytophthora infestans)
    • Early blight in tomatoes and potatoes (caused by Alternaria species)
  • Other options are animal or human diseases:
    • Botulism – Caused by Clostridium botulinum in humans and animals.
    • Coccidiosis – A parasitic disease affecting poultry and livestock.
    • Mastitis – Inflammation of the mammary gland in dairy animals.

Additional Information:

  • Plant diseases like blight affect agricultural productivity and are managed using fungicides, crop rotation, and resistant varieties.
  • Good sanitation and monitoring are essential for prevention.

question: __________ is a disorder resulting in abnormal electrical discharge from the brain cells causing seizures.
solution:
• Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by abnormal electrical activity in the brain, which leads to seizures.
  • Seizures may involve:
    • Uncontrolled movements
    • Loss of awareness or consciousness
    • Sensory disturbances
  • It can result from:
    • Brain injury
    • Genetic conditions
    • Infections like meningitis
    • Stroke or tumors
  • Other options:
    • Prostatitis – Inflammation of the prostate gland (in males)
    • Hypoglycaemia – Abnormally low blood sugar levels
    • Rheumatoid arthritis – Autoimmune disorder affecting joints

Additional Information:

  • Treatment includes anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs), surgery (in some cases), and lifestyle adjustments.
  • With proper management, many people with epilepsy live normal lives.

question: Which of the following is NOT a type of mosquito?
solution:
• Limulus is not a mosquito; it is the scientific name for the horseshoe crab, a marine arthropod.
  • The other three options are types of mosquitoes known for spreading various diseases:
    • Culex – Spreads filariasis and Japanese encephalitis
    • Aedes – Spreads dengue, chikungunya, Zika, yellow fever
    • Anopheles – Spreads malaria

Additional Information:

  • Limulus polyphemus is commonly used in biomedical research for its blue blood, which contains compounds that detect bacterial contamination.
  • Mosquito control is crucial for preventing vector-borne diseases.

question: Which of the following factors is responsible for the disease called “Mad Hatter Disease”?
solution:
• Mad Hatter Disease refers to a neurological disorder caused by chronic exposure to mercury, especially mercury vapors.
  • It gets its name from 19th-century hat makers who used mercury nitrate in hat-making and experienced tremors, mood swings, memory loss, and hallucinations.
  • The medical term for this condition is erethism or mercurialism.
  • Incorrect options:
    • Inhaling iron dust – can cause siderosis, a lung condition.
    • Inhaling silica dust – leads to silicosis, a lung disease.
    • Vitamin D deficiency – causes rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

Additional Information:

  • Symptoms of mercury poisoning include:
    • Tremors
    • Irritability
    • Insomnia
    • Memory problems
  • Mercury exposure can occur in industrial settings or via consumption of contaminated seafood.

question: Which of the following diseases is NOT caused by a flavivirus?
solution:
• Polio is not caused by a flavivirus; it is caused by the poliovirus, which belongs to the Picornaviridae family.
  • The other three diseases are caused by flaviviruses, which belong to the Flaviviridae family:
    • Yellow fever – caused by Yellow fever virus
    • Dengue – caused by Dengue virus
    • Japanese encephalitis – caused by Japanese encephalitis virus

Additional Information:

  • Flaviviruses are primarily arthropod-borne viruses (arboviruses), commonly transmitted by mosquitoes.
  • Polio is transmitted through the fecal-oral route, not via vectors like mosquitoes.
  • Vaccines are available for all these diseases, though the viruses differ in family and structure.

question: Which of the following diseases marked by dementia, diarrhoea, and dermatitis, is also known as ‘the three Ds’?
solution:
• Pellagra is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of niacin (Vitamin B3) or its precursor tryptophan in the diet.
  • It is classically identified by the “three Ds”:
    • Dementia (mental confusion and memory loss)
    • Diarrhoea
    • Dermatitis (skin inflammation and lesions)
  • If left untreated, a fourth D – death – may occur in severe cases.
  • Other options:
    • Osteoporosis – Loss of bone density, not related to niacin
    • Xerophthalmia – Caused by Vitamin A deficiency, leads to dry eyes
    • Scurvy – Caused by Vitamin C deficiency, leads to bleeding gums and fatigue

Additional Information:

  • Pellagra is common in populations relying heavily on maize (corn) as a staple, which lacks bioavailable niacin unless treated.
  • Treatment involves niacin supplementation and dietary changes.

question: Which of the following causative agents causes the disease Ebola?
solution:
• Ebola is caused by a virus, specifically the Ebola virus, which belongs to the Filoviridae family.
  • It causes a severe and often fatal hemorrhagic fever in humans and primates.
  • The virus spreads through direct contact with the blood, body fluids, or tissues of infected people or animals.
  • Incorrect options:
    • Bacteria – Cause diseases like tuberculosis, cholera
    • Fungi – Cause diseases like athlete’s foot, candidiasis
    • Protozoans – Cause diseases like malaria, amoebiasis

Additional Information:

  • Symptoms include: high fever, bleeding, vomiting, diarrhea, and organ failure.
  • Ebola outbreaks have primarily occurred in Sub-Saharan Africa.
  • There is no specific cure, but supportive care and experimental treatments have shown promise.

question: AMR occurs when bacteria, viruses, fungi and parasites change over time and no longer respond to medicines making infections harder to treat and increasing the risk of disease spread, severe illness and death. What is the full form of AMR?
solution:
• AMR stands for Antimicrobial Resistance.
  • It occurs when microorganisms (bacteria, viruses, fungi, parasites) evolve and become resistant to the drugs that were previously effective against them.
  • This makes infections harder to treat, leading to longer illness durations, higher medical costs, and increased mortality.
  • Incorrect options:
    • Acute Microbial Resistance – Not a recognized term
    • Antimalarial Resistance – A specific type of resistance, but not the full form of AMR
    • Anti Measles Resistance – Not relevant to the concept of AMR

Additional Information:

  • Overuse and misuse of antibiotics in humans and animals are major drivers of AMR.
  • AMR is a growing global public health threat.
  • Common examples: MRSA, drug-resistant TB, and multi-drug resistant malaria.

question: What is another name for the disorder called ‘parasomnia’?
solution:
• Parasomnia refers to a group of sleep disorders involving abnormal behaviors, movements, emotions, perceptions, or dreams that occur while falling asleep, during sleep, or during arousal from sleep.
  • One of the most well-known forms of parasomnia is sleepwalking, also called somnambulism.
  • It typically occurs during deep non-REM sleep and is most common in children.
  • Incorrect options:
    • Night blindness – A vision disorder caused by Vitamin A deficiency
    • Seasickness – A motion sickness caused by disturbance in the inner ear
    • Stammering – A speech disorder involving repetition or blockage of speech sounds

Additional Information:

  • Other examples of parasomnia include night terrors, bedwetting (enuresis), sleep talking, and REM sleep behavior disorder.
  • Causes may include stress, sleep deprivation, medications, or neurological conditions.

question: Trachoma is a preventable disease that results from poor hygiene and sanitation. Which of the following body parts does it affect?
solution:
• Trachoma is a bacterial infection that affects the eyes.
  • It is caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • It is preventable and primarily linked to poor hygiene and sanitation, especially in areas lacking clean water and proper waste disposal.
  • The infection causes:
    • Conjunctivitis (pink eye)
    • Repeated infections that lead to eyelid scarring
    • In-turned eyelashes (trichiasis) which scratch the cornea
    • Blindness in severe, untreated cases
  • Incorrect options:
    • Ear – Not affected by trachoma
    • Stomach – Trachoma is not gastrointestinal
    • Heart – Not involved in this condition

Additional Information:

  • Trachoma is one of the leading causes of preventable blindness globally.
  • Prevention includes:
    • Facial cleanliness
    • Access to clean water
    • Antibiotic treatment and, in severe cases, surgery

question: Which of the following diseases is caused by Helicobacter pylori?
solution:
• Gastritis is an inflammation of the stomach lining, and one of its major causes is infection by the bacterium Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori).
  • H. pylori survives in the acidic environment of the stomach and can damage the protective mucosal layer, leading to:
    • Gastritis
    • Peptic ulcers
    • In some cases, stomach cancer
  • Incorrect options:
    • Ringworm – A fungal infection of the skin, not bacterial
    • Chikungunya – A viral disease transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes
    • Rubella – A viral infection, also known as German measles

Additional Information:

  • H. pylori infection is common globally and often spreads through contaminated food, water, or utensils.
  • Diagnosis: urea breath test, stool antigen test, endoscopy
  • Treatment: combination of antibiotics and acid-reducing medications

question: The cause of Siderosis is excessive deposition of __________ in the body tissue.
solution:
• Siderosis is a condition caused by the excessive deposition of iron in body tissues, especially in the lungs.
  • It commonly affects workers who inhale iron dust, such as:
    • Welders
    • Miners
    • Foundry workers
  • The iron particles accumulate in the lungs, leading to lung tissue damage and, in severe cases, respiratory issues.
  • Incorrect options:
    • Aluminium – Causes Aluminosis
    • Coal – Causes Anthracosis (black lung disease)
    • Zinc – Excess may cause other issues but not siderosis

Additional Information:

  • Siderosis is considered a type of pneumoconiosis, which includes lung diseases caused by inhaling mineral dust.
  • It is generally non-fibrotic, but prolonged exposure can worsen lung function.
  • Prevention includes using proper respiratory protection and controlling dust exposure in workplaces.

question: Which of the following diseases damages the eye’s optic nerve and results in vision loss and blindness and occurs when the normal fluid pressure inside the eyes slowly rises?
solution:
• Glaucoma is a group of eye diseases that damage the optic nerve, often due to increased intraocular pressure (IOP) — the pressure of fluid inside the eye.
  • Over time, this pressure damages the optic nerve, leading to progressive vision loss and potentially blindness if untreated.
  • It is one of the leading causes of irreversible blindness worldwide.
  • Incorrect options:
    • Vitiligo – A skin disorder causing loss of pigmentation
    • Psoriasis – A chronic skin condition causing red, scaly patches
    • Gonorrhea – A sexually transmitted bacterial infection; can affect eyes in newborns, but not in the same way as glaucoma

Additional Information:

  • Glaucoma often has no early symptoms, which is why it is called the “silent thief of sight.”
  • Diagnosis includes tonometry (pressure test), visual field testing, and optic nerve imaging.
  • Treatment: eye drops, oral medications, laser therapy, or surgery.

question: Leukaemia is a cancer of the:
solution:
• Leukaemia is a type of cancer of the blood or bone marrow, specifically affecting the white blood cells (WBCs).
  • In leukaemia, the body produces abnormally high numbers of immature or dysfunctional white blood cells, which interfere with the normal functioning of blood and immune response.
  • These abnormal cells accumulate in the bone marrow and crowd out healthy cells.
  • Incorrect options:
    • Skin – Cancers like melanoma affect the skin.
    • Lungs – Lung cancer originates in the lungs.
    • Uterus – Uterine or cervical cancer affects the uterus.

Additional Information:

  • Types of leukaemia include:
    • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)
    • Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML)
    • Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL)
    • Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML)
  • Symptoms: fatigue, frequent infections, bleeding/bruising, weight loss
  • Treatment: chemotherapy, radiation therapy, bone marrow transplant

question: Nyctophobia is the fear of:
solution:
• Nyctophobia is the irrational and extreme fear of darkness or night.
  • It commonly develops in childhood, but can persist into adulthood if not addressed.
  • People with nyctophobia may feel:
    • Panic or anxiety in dark environments
    • Rapid heartbeat
    • Sweating or trembling
  • Incorrect options:
    • Ornithophobia – Fear of birds
    • Zoophobia – Fear of animals
    • Photophobia – Sensitivity or fear of light

Additional Information:

  • Nyctophobia may be rooted in evolutionary instincts – humans are naturally cautious in the dark due to visibility and safety concerns.
  • Treatment may include:
    • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
    • Gradual exposure therapy
    • Relaxation techniques and counseling
